modnlp.tc.classify
Class BVBayes

java.lang.Object
  modnlp.tc.classify.BVBayes
public class BVBayes
extends java.lang.Object

Naive Bayes classifier for documents represented as Boolean vectors. This class uses the CSV described in (Sebastiani, 2002). CSV values are not probabilities but the function is monotonically increasing on the estimated probability function. Categorise each news item in corpus_list according to categ using Boolean Vector Naive Bayes (see lecture notes ctinduction.pdf, p 7) Usage: 

 BVBayes corpus_list categ prob_model 

SYNOPSIS:
  Categorise each news item in corpus_list according to categ using
  Boolean Vector Naive Bayes (see lecture notes ctinduction.pdf, p 7)

ARGUMENTS
 corpus_list: list of files to be classified

 categ: target category (e.g. 'acq'.) The classifier will define CSV 
        as CSV_{categ}

 pmfile: file containing a  probability model generated via, say, 
         modnlp.tc.induction.MakeProbabilityModel.

See Also:
BVProbabilityModel, NewsParser

 double computeCSV(java.lang.String cat, ParsedDocument pni)
          CSV_i(d_j) = \sum_0^T tkj log p(t|c) * (1 - p(t|?c) / p(t|?c) * (1 - p(t|c) (where tkj \in {0, 1} is the binary weight at position k in vector d_j; multiplying by it causes terms that do not occur in the document to be ignored) Disadvantage of this approach: larger documents receive disproportionally large CSV's simply by virtue of containing more terms.

computeCSV

public double computeCSV(java.lang.String cat,
                         ParsedDocument pni)
CSV_i(d_j) = \sum_0^T tkj log p(t|c) * (1 - p(t|?c) / p(t|?c) * (1 - p(t|c) (where tkj \in {0, 1} is the binary weight at position k in vector d_j; multiplying by it causes terms that do not occur in the document to be ignored) Disadvantage of this approach: larger documents receive disproportionally large CSV's simply by virtue of containing more terms. Document lenght normalisation could be employed here to correct this distortion. A simpler approach would be to base the probability model on term events rather than document events, as described in (Mitchell 97, ch 6).

main

public static void main(java.lang.String[] args)
